author: sky.cactus
content: I think 99% of people will not validate *after* the sync is done.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is just way too easy to forget to do that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, you are running in "trust the state provider" mode from initial sync until you validate the results.  If the results are wrong, you have to start over.  If you fail to validate (e.g., you forget) then you are running in "trust the state provider" mode indefinitely.

author: potuz
content: But that's a different story: you don't  **have** to trust, but yeah people are lazy (including myself) and if I find myself following the same chain as beaconcha.in, probably will think it's fine.

author: sky.cactus
content: My general argument is that current state sync design is fully trusted, but you can follow the current state sync and then do extra stuff afterwards to switch to untrusted.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you do a fast sync today though, you are fully trusting the state provider unless you follow an additional *separate process* to convert to an untrusted setup afterwards.

author: m.kalinin
content: An improvement that you may be referring to is in the proposal stage now https://github.com/ethereum/beacon-APIs/pull/226. There are debates on exposing more data endpoints which I don't think make sense as it is against the original idea of the proposal to reduce the complexity of becoming a state provider. Some CL clients require a full block aside the state to be bootstrapped and will need to make the change to their code (the change may be non trivial) to be able to do a fresh start with the state only. I am echoing Micah that it is unlikely to be adopted by the network before the Merge

author: parithosh
content: Yea we plan to, Sam is currently working on getting some tooling in place so that it's really easy to setup the checkpoint sync instances in a safe way. We hope to have things ready before the mainnet merge, with a guide on how to join.

author: samcm
content:
https://github.com/samcm/checkpointz is what i've been working on for this - hopefully it'll be ready to run relatively soon. We'll probably also create some guides/documentation for running an endpoint if operators don't want to run `checkpointz` (e.g. with just a web server in front of a beacon node) üëç 

We (EF DevOps) will only run a mainnet endpoint if we are one-of-many, but the intention is that we can reduce the friction of running an endpoint to the point where there is no need for EF to run one at all.

author: sky.cactus
content: What percentage of validators are required to reach finality?

author: sky.cactus
content: ~~Is it 75%?~~ Looks like it is 66%.

author: arnetheduck
content: strictly, it's based on "active balance" and not "number-of-validators", the active balance being the sum of the effective balances of active validators, and effective balance being their balance, capped to 32eth (more or less): https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/phase0/beacon-chain.md#justification-and-finalization
